title: Feature request: _.ladder
body:
Function signature:
```
_.ladder([string=''], separator, [limit]);

Arguments

[string=''] (string): The string to split.
separator (string): The separator to split by.
[limit] (number): The length to truncate results to.

Returns
(Array): Returns the string segments as ladder.
```
How to work:
```javascript
_.ladder('str:str2:str3', ':'); //return array ['str', 'str:str2', 'str:str2:str3']
```

Hello guys,

just encountered a weird bug which can be reproduced with the following line:

`_.chain([1]).map(function(x) { return x + 2; }).get('1') >= 1`

Enter this line in the console in IE 11 (for example on the lodash homepage) and the browser window will freeze.

title: startCase incorrectly handles plural acronyms (e.g. IVAs & CCJs)

_.get Documentation Update Proposal
body:
What
-
The documentation for the `_.get` function does not fully portray its functionality.

Why
-
I've had to explain and show 4 people today that the `_.get` function works with arrays by pulling up the source code and giving examples in the console. This is a tell-tale sign of poor documentation for the function. 

Proposal
-
We should update the documentation for the `_.get` function to something along the lines of:
```js
 import baseGet from './.internal/baseGet.js'

/**
 * Gets the value at `path` of `object`. If the resolved value is
 * `undefined`, the `defaultValue` is returned in its place.
 *
 * @since 3.7.0
 * @category Object
 * @param {Object|Array} collection The collection to query.
 * @param {Array|string} path The path of the property to get.
 * @param {*} [defaultValue] The value returned for `undefined` resolved values.
 * @returns {*} Returns the resolved value.
 * @see has, hasIn, set, unset
 * @example
 * const array = [{ 'b': { 'c': 3 } }]
 * const object = { 'a': array }
 *
 * get(object, 'a[0].b.c')
 * // => 3
 *
 * get(object, ['a', '0', 'b', 'c'])
 * // => 3
 *
 * get(object, 'a.b.c', 'default')
 * // => 'default'
 *
 * get(array, 0)
 * // => { 'b': { 'c': 3 } }
 *
 * get(array, '[0].b')
 * // => { 'c': 3 }
 *
 * get(array, 1)
 * // => undefined
 */
function get(object, path, defaultValue) {
  const result = object == null ? undefined : baseGet(object, path)
  return result === undefined ? defaultValue : result
}

export default get
```
Example Explanations
-
The examples within the new documentation will show that arrays can:
- return resolved values when passed an index
- return resolved values when passed a path
- return `undefined` when passed an index that is out of bounds instead of throwing a runtime error

P.S.
-
This technically doesn't add new functionality since it is already implemented but does provide a feature to those who strictly adhere to documentation over reading source code. As documented, this codebase requires issues for features so here it is.

I am willing to update tests and the documentation if this proposal is accepted.

title: .camelCase() issue (?) when string contains numbers
body:
Hi, :-)

When:
1. `_.camelCase('i18n-locales')`
2. ` _.camelCase('r2d2Voice')`
3. `_.camelCase('c8yHello-widget')`

Expected:
1. `i18nLocales`
2. `r2d2Voice`
3. `c8yHelloWidget`

Actual:
1. `i18NLocales`
2. `r2D2Voice`
3. `c8YHelloWidget`

Is this behaviour expected somehow?

title: Could we reduce lodash size?
body:
Hi!

I see lodash es6 build is on the go, this is amazing, thank you @jdalton & contribs a lot!

The problem I've recently faced with was the following: I never use Buffers / Streams (obviously) & ArrayViews / Symbols / Maps / Sets (because of a browser support) on the client. Thus I don't need any related code to be bundled in my final client build. As far as there are no more libs like lodash, our current solution was to reimplement most of the lodash methods and port the tests, which resulted into reducing the final bundle size by 3 times.

I wonder if we can do something similar with lodash? The most obvious way to do this (as I see it) is to cover code with guards:
```
if (IS_SERVER_BUILD) {
 // code which work with buffers
}
```
then strip it out with `uglify` and ship 2 builds: `lodash-server` & `lodash-client`.

Actually, I'm not sure this is important to many lodash users, but still think it worth asking.

Should toNumber handle commas ?

Hello,

The toNumber (valid for toInteger as well) converts a valid number composed string into a number. 

`_.toNumber('13.37')` will return 13.37 as a number
Why doesn't `_.toNumber('4,2')` return 4.2 as a number ?

If it is a wanted behaviour then please ignore this question, but if it is not it could avoid the use of `.replace(',', '.')`

title: Resolving a Promise without any argument breaks in some browsers
body:
### Background

Promise.resolve without any argument throws an error with

```
TypeError: Expected at least one argument
```

This happens in lg (smarttv) and webmaf browsers

### Proposed Solution

Resolve with ``undefined``so the check passes and still keep the previous behavior.

title: Changes to _.reject() not listed in changelog
body:
In v3.10.1, `_.reject()` takes up to 3 arguments https://lodash.com/docs/3.10.1#reject
In v4.0.0, `_.reject()` takes only 2 arguments https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#reject

This is a breaking change yet it is not mentioned in the changelog at https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Changelog, which it should be.

title: Feature request: _.reargAt function wrapper
body:
Hello,

I recently ran into a case where I had to implement a wrapper function in order to destructure its argument :
`const saveStatusValue = ({ value }) => saveStatus(value)`

I didn't find anything helpful in lodash, I would have liked a combination of `rearg` and `at` like this :
`_.reargAt(func, paths)`
with arguments :
`func (Function)`: The function to rearrange arguments for.
`[paths] (...(string|string[]))`: The property paths to use as arguments.

Which in my case would give :
`const saveStatusValue = _.reargAt(saveStatus, '0.value')`

Another example with several arguments :
`saveOrderStatusValue = (status, order) => saveOrderStatus(order.id, status.value)`
would give :
`saveOrderStatusValue = _.reargAt(saveOrderStatus, ['1.id', '0.value'])`

Hope this could be helpful to other people :smile:

title: Calling a curried function with no parameters does not register as a call
body:
When trying to call a curried function with a fixed number of parameters I've found that when dealing with the last argument if I try to call the function without providing a parameter I am simply returned the identity of the function I am currying. However, providing `undefined` or `null` behaves as expected.


``` javascript
let foo = _.curry(x => 5, 2);

foo(4)(null); //  5
foo(4)();     //  x => 5
```

Is this the intended behavior here? Any insight would be appreciated.

title: _.reduce doesn't work without supplying accumulator
body:
The signature of `_.reduce` indicates that the accumulator is an optional argument. However, in TypeScript, not supplying the accumulator results in the compiler throwing an error:

```
Type '{}' is not assignable to type 'number'.
```

Here is an example: 
```
let numbers: number[] = [1, 2, 3];
let result = _.reduce(x, (accum, value, idx, coll) => value + accum);
```

As soon as I provide a value for the accumulator, the error goes away.

title: Increase performance of lodash.sample
body:
Increase performance by 30-120% depending if `null` is provided or not.

**bench.js**
```javascript
  .add('sample', () => { sample(['a', 'b', 'c']) })
  .add('sample null', () => { sample(null) })
  .add('sample []', () => { sample([]) })
  .add('lodash.sample', () => { _.sample(['a', 'b', 'c']) })
  .add('lodash.sample null', () => { _.sample(null) })
  .add('lodash.sample []', () => { _.sample([]) })
```
Benchmark results
```
sample x 60,896,314 ops/sec Â±0.44% (94 runs sampled)
sample null x 115,404,510 ops/sec Â±0.70% (95 runs sampled)
sample [] x 84,197,168 ops/sec Â±0.79% (90 runs sampled)
lodash.sample x 44,758,830 ops/sec Â±0.59% (94 runs sampled)
lodash.sample null x 50,702,929 ops/sec Â±0.55% (91 runs sampled)
lodash.sample [] x 54,129,884 ops/sec Â±0.56% (89 runs sampled)
```

title: Lodash vs Lodash FP, performance-wise
body:
I've tried my best to find some sort of analysis or at least a benchmark, but got nothing.

I'm aware that `lodash/fp` merely wraps the existing functions, instead of re-implementing them, but it would be nice to have a definitive performance-based answer to **"Should I use the FP variant or the regular one in this case?"**. For example, is there some sort of a penalty, when running `fp.reduce(reducer, '')(arr)` instead of `_.reduce(arr, reducer, '')` many times in a loop? Would that put more load on GC, or consume more memory, or introduce other types of overhead?

I've tried benchmarking myself, but jsPerf isn't working properly, and I'm getting weird/inconsistent results on alternative services, and I just don't have time to make something custom, unfortunately.

_.remove doesn't play nice with Vue
body:
There's an issue when using lodash with Vue when you want to remove a value from a reactive array. The situation is explained clearly here: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/2673

Vue captures the `splice` call on the array, but because lodash uses Array.splice directly, that capture never takes place, and the observer is never notified.

Q: Why does lodash use `Array.prototype` instead of calling `splice` directly on the subject array?

title: _merge converts Buffer property to Array when dest property is also a buffer
body:
Hi
When working with "merge" function i noticed than when destination and source properties are Buffers then destination property is converted to Array which results in stack trace (missing toString function).
This issue only exists when source property exists.

example:
```
var _ = require('lodash');
var testStr = 'Lorem Ipsum';
let obj1 = { foo: Buffer.from(testStr) };
let obj2 = { foo: Buffer.from(testStr) };

_.merge(obj1,obj2);
console.log('isBuffer(obj1.foo) = ', Buffer.isBuffer(obj1.foo));
console.log('isBuffer(obj2.foo) = ', Buffer.isBuffer(obj2.foo));
```

The Results are:
```
isBuffer(obj1.foo) =  false
isBuffer(obj2.foo) =  true
```

**Workaround is to use "lodash/fp" or use "mergeWith" and a customizer function**

Is this OK?
- If Yes then the issue can be closed
- If No then the solution would be to modify baseMergeDeep function and change the order of checking of objValue (move isArrayLikeObject(objValue) after checking if "isBuff" is true), but I'm not sure if this would be the right solutions.

Thank You
Tomasz

title: Cache does not need to implement the full Map interface... or does it?
body:
This issue is more a discussion than a proper lodash issue right now. Depending on the outcome, it's likely to become a docs issue.

I'm starting this discussion because I found myself interested in implementing various cache strategies but didn't feel comfortable with what the doc was asking from me.

>  **Note:** The cache is exposed as the `cache` property on the memoized function. Its creation may be customized by replacing the `memoize.Cache` constructor with one whose instances implement the [`Map`](http://ecma-international.org/ecma-262/7.0/#sec-properties-of-the-map-prototype-object) method interface of `clear`, `delete`, `get`, `has`, and `set`.

[source](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/3c5b828d7e0460812e2a24605a91ed5c8130d287/memoize.js#L10-L14)

However, the only methods [used](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/3c5b828d7e0460812e2a24605a91ed5c8130d287/memoize.js#L53-L57) by `memoize` are get/set/has.
So, for memoize to work, the Cache constructor does not need to create objects that implement more than that. Note that it's the reason `WeakMap` is a valid option despite lacking a `clear` method.

There exists a usage of [cache.clear and cache.size](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/3c5b828d7e0460812e2a24605a91ed5c8130d287/.internal/memoizeCapped.js#L17-L18) in the internals.
The bad news is that WeakMap does not implement either. The good news is that the only user of `.internal/memoizeCapped` so far is [stringToPath](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/085dc1aa01783e0ce924f39f2b2ed5464c4572e1/.internal/stringToPath.js) and in a way that does not enable user code to change `memoize.Cache` before the `memoizeCapped` call.

It's not 100% clear (pun intended) whether the good news is luck or deliberate. In case of luck, then it means WeakMap is disqualified? should any Cache also implement a `size` property?
In case it's deliberate, maybe a comment in `.internal/memoizeCapped`/`stringToPath` would be useful to express intent.

title: Lodash/fp functions
body:
Hi,

I moved recently from Ramda to lodash/fp and first of all thank you for a great library!

I have problems finding some functions in lodash:
- `and` and `or` functions that would take pair (or array) of boolean values and return false/true
- `.ap` - applicative function that will dispatch `ap` function on functor/monad
- `.map` / `.filter` / `.chain` / `.flatMap` - just to be sure - they are dispatching second argument's map, if present?
- lenses? do you have any support for them?

Thanks in advance,

Kamil

title: _.mapKeys(object, ...) fails in TypeScript if object is type Object
body:
I noticed that in TypeScript, if I call _mapKeys(object, ...) with object being type Object, TypeScript gives the following error when it tries to compile:
`error TS2345: Argument of type 'Object' is not assignable to parameter of type 'List<{}> | Dictionary<{}>'`
Is this expected behaviour?

Thanks.

title: Lodash FP map doesn't take index as second argument
body:
I was expecting to see the ```1,2,3``` in the following fiddle:

https://jsfiddle.net/bdjq1doq/
Is this expected behavior?

title: startCase converts umlauts into non-umlauts
body: `startCase('Ã¤Ã¶Ã¼Ã')` will be transformed to 'aouss'

title: `get` and `set` strip backslashes from paths when using array notation and quotes
`clone` with extended Array throws Exception
body:
Were I `clone()` extended Array (`class Foo extends Array`) I'd catch `TypeError: Class constructor Foo cannot be invoked without 'new'`. 
Would you add `new` op in [this row](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/59a9eb6e0175198c4ec45e48764edb6858597d2d/.internal/initCloneArray.js#L13)? Thanks!

title: Should `toPairs` take a `Collection`?
body:
So far I have not found any instance where `toPairs` fails to work on a simple array (though admittedly, the output of array indices as strings is a bit of a "gotcha"). However in the official documentation, the parameter for `toPairs` is an Object. This makes me nervous to use `toPairs` on arrays because the lack of documentation implies that my use case could possibly receive a breaking change in even a patch-level version bump.

I assume that the `Object` parameter is not intended to also include `Array` because there's a separate `Collection` parameter type.

Would it be possible to enshrine the use of `toPairs` on arrays in the docs by re-specifying it as a `Collection` method? If I've misunderstood the relationship between `Object`, `Array`, and `Collection`, could the docs add clarification on that point?

Thanks for your time.

title: Why is `lower` optional in `clamp`?
body:
Would changing this function from `_.clamp(number, [lower], upper)` to `_.clamp(number, lower, upper)` be considered for the next major version? I don't understand the value of allowing `lower` to be optional.

- If I'm intentionally excluding that parameter (`_.clamp(n, 100)`), isn't that just `_.max`?
- If I'm unintentionally excluding it (`_.clamp(n, min, max)`, where `max` is sometimes `undefined`), then I get very unexpected results (`min` is sometimes treated as `max`).

title: Fix package.json to include some missing fields and keywords.
body: Hi, I added a few fields that I noticed were missing from the package.json file. I've also added some keywords that I felt described the project for it to be picked up by npmjs.
